item.title: Conjugate vs Power match
item.description: An RF transistor is like a child. It needs the right environment to perform well. The load you present at the input and output terminals of the transistor determine the performance you will get from it.

item.title: Create Flywheels in Engineering Work
item.description: Use engineering flywheels to greatly increase your work or team output. Engineering work is resource intensive and sometimes there is no capacity to throw more inputs into a project on a deadline.

item.title: Don't be the loudest voice in the room
item.description: You’re not doing yourself a favor by being the loudest voice in the room. There’s this thing called the Dunning-Kruger effect People with imposter syndrome will not speak up

item.title: Education via substack is more beneficial that traditional teaching styles
item.description: I’ve always wanted to teach but going in to professorship seems a long drawn out path Tenure track Lower pay compared to industry Universities are in odd places Limited reach Lack of modern techniques Doing it online is a great way

item.title: Have fringe knowledge to be a great engineer
item.description: A truly innovative engineer is not one who knows the topic in depth. The greatest contributions in an engineering team are often made by those who have “fringe knowledge”

item.title: High Gatekeeping standards for Semiconductor EEs
item.description: If you need a Phd to do EE work (which you dont always need- you can be trained to perform specific tasks), then not many people want to do it.

item.title: How amazing you can tell wave properties from circuit elements
item.description: You tell me what the dimensions of the line are, I’ll tell you how fast the signal travels. I’m amazed this can even be calculated.

item.description: Samuel J. Mason had the most bass-ackwards approach to identify a fundamental property of linear two-port networks. What most people would do- Find the expression for power gain of a linear 2-port, maximize it and prove that it’s an invariant property.

item.title: What happens to an amplifier in compression?
item.description: When input signal to an amplifier is high, the output power and gain drops. The amplifier is in compression. But where does this power go?

item.title: What I learnt from reading software engineering newsletters
What should a RF bootcamp focused on fundamentals should look like
item.description: Here’s what a good RF fundamentals bootcamp should look like: üëáüèº Network Theory - learn impedances, S/Z/Y matrices Electromagnetics - Gauss law, ampere’s law, maxwells equations, visualize fields Antenna fundamentals - basic terminology and operating principle Transmission lines - telegrapher equations (waveguides optional) Passive microwave circuits - couplers, power dividers, basic filters Basic RF devices - mosfets, BJTs Active microwave circuits - Amplifiers and mixers RF systems - block diagram, performance design, modulation basics I do understand each of these can be their own book.

item.title: What's your biggest challenge to learning as an engineer?

item.title: Why RF Engineers should learn programming?
item.description: Most RF engineers do not prioritize programming as one of their skill sets. Instead, they manually repeat far too many tasks related to data analysis, lab measurements and format translations.

item.title: Why RF Engineers should show smith charts where possible

item.title: William Shockley
item.description: He was silicon valley’s first entrepreneur and also the worst engineering manager ever. These famous people worked for him: Gordon Moore and Robert Noyce (Intel) Walter Brattain and John Bardeen (Nobel prize) Jean Hoerni (inventor of planar process) Jay Last (significant contributions to silicon integrated circuits) Eugene Kleiner (founder of one of the first silicon valley VC firms) He is William Shockley.

item.title: Working deeply as an engineer

item.title: Working on personal projects
item.description: You are not spending as much time on personal projects as you should. Both the company and your skillset will stand to benefit.

item.title: Write down one engineering learning per day
item.description: Here’s a simple way to supercharge your engineering learning. Write down one thing you have learned everyday. You would have learned 30 concepts in a month.
